headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: Magic Mushrooms: Can They Change Your Mind?. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: DAVID CULVER, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Overall, it's been just something that I've sat with and kind of have a peace of mind.

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: All right. Fascinating. That's what they call reporter involvement. David Culver, thanks very much. Can't wait to see the episodes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Jim.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Really appreciate it. Don't miss this new episode of The Whole Story With Anderson Cooper. It starts next. Only on CNN. Reporting from Washington, I'm Jim Acosta. Thank you very much for joining me this evening. I'll see you next weekend. Have a great week, everybody.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to The Whole Story, I'm Anderson Cooper. You've probably heard of Magic Mushrooms, mushrooms which contains psilocybin, a natural substance that can cause hallucinations when ingested.Magic Mushrooms became popular in the United States in the 1960s. But in the last decade, there's been an increasing amount of research into psilocybin to see if it can help treat depression, anxiety, and substance abuse. Magic Mushrooms are still illegal on the federal level, but a few states have decriminalized them, and this year, Oregon became the first state to legalize the use of psilocybin in licensed therapy centers. There's still a lot we don't know about psilocybins affecting the brain long-term, and many are asking if it's too soon to offer these treatments. Over the next hour, CNN's David Culver takes us into this fascinating new world and takes us on a mind-altering journey of his own. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Embarking on a psychedelic trip --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: -- requires a willingness to be vulnerable to hold nothing back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This wasn't easy, I imagine for any of you to just say, yes, let me jump in. And you're here for a reason.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Documenting it with cameras for a story to be shared with the world? Well, that suggest a near total surrender to the unknown.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Let go. Let go with it and just go with the flow.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: The experiences you're about to witness, they're intimate, they're exhilarating and exhausting.After taking a dose of psilocybin, the psychoactive compound in Magic Mushrooms, you wait.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Psilocybin bring you what you need, not to what you want.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And slowly, the plant medicine, as they call it, takes hold.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You're your own guide, you're your own healer. You're going to tap into your inner self.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: You feel at first in your body, then your mind.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm praying that like this or this happens.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Before showing you how this all plays out, we got to first set the scene. We're in Jamaica, staying at a place called Coral Cove. It's where a company called Silo Wellness host therapeutic psychedelic retreats using magic mushrooms, legal to grow and consume here in Jamaica.The picturesque setting aim to help us disconnect from the stories we've told ourselves about our own past and reconnect to something much deeper.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The integration after ceremony is where your real journey begins. How do you bring it all together and make the changes that have come to you?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hey. How's it going, guys?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: We're here with a handful of participants who put aside their lives in the U.S. for this five-day retreat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What I'd love to do today is just get all your voices into this space, it's a safe space.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: They hope Magic Mushrooms might bring them answers and healing. But taking this deeply personal journey is not cheap. It cost several thousand dollars, part of a burgeoning billion dollar industry that's now legal and soon available in the U.S.But the journey to this point started weeks earlier.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Hadie [ph]. How are you? UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You want to go the same length? I have it on my notes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Originally from Ecuador, Johanna Buitron now lives in Los Angeles, working as a cosmetic tattoo artist. She admits, beneath the facade of external beauty, she feels lost.It sounded like you were on this path of finding fulfillment, right?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Have you ever taken mushrooms?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Um-um. Never.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: So this will be your first too?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: This will be my first time.

utterances.speaker: JASON MOSS, FEDERAL BANKRUPTCY ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: I'm out of town next week, let's have Christian, Christian cover my news.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Across the country in Columbia, South Carolina.J. MOSS: What number am I looking for?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Jason Moss, also turning to psilocybin for the first time. On the outside, you see this successful federal bankruptcy attorney, he's charismatic, really engaging, but his addiction, he's kept private. Until now.J. MOSS: Alcohol is something I've been struggling with for years. I've been lucky it hasn't affected my daily life at work, but I think it has affected my home life. And it's something where I'd like to, instead of having the urge to drink when I get stressed. To have that feeling, hey, I don't want to do that. And right now, it's difficult to have that out of my system. I would like almost like a fresh start, a fresh start on just rethinking how and why I drink.

utterances.speaker: FRED BARRETT, ACTING DIRECTOR, JOHNS HOPKINS CTR, FOR PSYCHEDELIC AND CONSCIOUSNESS RESEARCH
utterances.sentences: There's an awful lot of excitement and an awful lot of hype, built up now around the potential for psychedelics as a new treatment in psychiatry. And a really radically effective treatment. That's the promise, that's the hope, and that's the hype.There's also a really great potential for something called therapeutic misconception. It's the misconception that because we're studying it, it must work.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: As research explores the potential benefits of mushrooms, we should remind you, they've been around for a while.

utterances.speaker: TOM ECKERT, PROGRAM DIRECTOR, INNERTREK
utterances.sentences: This is an ancient medicine, you know, it has been used for hundreds, if not thousands of years in ceremonial context.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: This so-called medicine, making a comeback in what some are calling a psychedelic's renaissance, and showing promise in treating multiple conditions like depression, anxiety, and substance abuse.

utterances.speaker: BARRETT
utterances.sentences: Psychedelic drugs were first discovered by Western society in the '40s and the '50s. And from that point forward, a number of folks around the world began to study these drugs to understand their potential effects on consciousness, to understand the potential therapeutic effects.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: That was until the late '60s, when a growing counterculture movement, along with a reckless use of psychedelics led to the war on drugs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: America's public enemy number one in the United States is drug abuse.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And with that, research on psychedelics halted.What do you make of the past few decades and how psychedelics have been characterized? ROBIN CARHART-HARRIS, PROFESSOR OF NEUROLOGY AND PSYCHIATRY, UCSF AND INNERTREK ADVISOR: I just think it was fear, you know, people didn't know enough. And they were very much influenced by the stories that created a kind of alarmist sensationalism around psychedelics.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Now, after decades of, quote, prohibition, we're seeing a new wave of research, and it's shifting the narrative.What do you think overall, though, has less than that fear? CARHART-HARRIS: Evidence, without question. There being some new evidence now for the safety and potential efficacy of psychedelics and more specifically psychedelic therapy for things like depression, end- of-life distress, addiction. J. MOSS: It starts actually on Tuesday --

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Jason, desperately wants to be proof that psilocybin works.J. MOSS: I was watching a documentary this one gentleman, he was at NYU study, and he took the medicine and he said it was like similar. Just take an antibiotic, took it just one day, and he was better. If it works out something like that, that would be fantastic. And that would be --

utterances.speaker: PATRICK MOSS, JASON MOSS SON
utterances.sentences: You got to let it though. It's not going to like guaranteed that's why -- it's like I agree with it, but if you go in there expecting, it's just going to work. And then you have like a craving or a thought. You're going to tell yourself that that just didn't work. Instead of like, it's -- I feel like you got to put in a little bit to it.J. MOSS: Oh, yes, I think it's going to be with effort. P. MOSS: But you're -- also, it sounds like you're ready.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Soaring over Oregon sprawling coastline, and above its majestic mountains, you might miss the small but mighty mushroom and those hoping to harness its potential. In 2020, Oregon residents voted to legalize psilocybin for therapeutic use, the first state in the U.S. to do so. In January, the law took effect.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And you get to decide how big you want the group to be. It requires those who will administer psilocybin or facilitators to be trained and certified.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: During the role plays, there might be some whispering. I want to make sure you can hear everything that's happening.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Courses aimed to help facilitators guide others through a range of psychedelic trips.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So like to invite all of us to focus inwardly. We take a couple deep breaths and just notice what's happening inside.

utterances.speaker: ECKERT
utterances.sentences: When you're facilitating the group session, it's non- directive. It's not -- it's not talk therapy.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: The season therapist, Tom Eckert, is with Innertrek, a new company founded to train facilitators in Oregon.Tom and his late wife played a big role in bringing legalized psilocybin therapy services to the state.

utterances.speaker: ECKERT
utterances.sentences: We were the first to bring this idea forward that maybe there's a campaign to bring this into existence.It passed in Oregon with 55 percent of the vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And maybe start to notice your breath. CULVERInnertrek plans to open one in Portland. They'll all be required to use mushrooms from licensed labs.

utterances.speaker: ECKERT
utterances.sentences: We want to make sure that the products are up to standard and that the doses are standardized so people know what they're getting.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: For now, it will be pricey and not covered by insurance.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Sounds promising, but by no means a cure all.

utterances.speaker: BARRETT
utterances.sentences: Psychedelics may not be entirely safe for people who have a personal or family history of psychosis. Patients with bipolar disorder may be at great risk of taking psychedelic drugs and having another manic episode.

utterances.speaker: ECKERT
utterances.sentences: The risks come in more psychologically, right? Because without support, in some cases, it could be destabilizing.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Some medical experts fear it's all moving too quickly in Oregon.DANIEL NICOLI, LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE CO-CHAIRMAN, OREGON PSYCHIATRIC PHYSICIANS ASSOCIATION: The one thing that does worry me is this trend where we're bypassing the FDA and other safeguards to kind of determine what is the safe medicine? Are we informing people of the risks? Do we even know the risks?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Another concern is that facilitators only have to have a high school degree.

utterances.speaker: ECKERT
utterances.sentences: Some people come at it from a different angle. And we're not trying to close those people out. We want those people.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm thinking about couples who might want to do a session themselves.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Seth Mehr is among those that planning to offer psilocybin treatment. He happens to be a former ER doctor.Was there a point you said to yourself, we should be trying a different courses of treatment or medication?

utterances.speaker: SETH MEHR, FOUNDER, CASCADE PSYCHEDELIC MEDICINE
utterances.sentences: I would see the same patients who are getting kind of standard psychiatric medications, therapy, who really are just not being served by the system. It was a personal journey with psychedelics that really made me realize that some of the most powerful medicines were being locked away.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: What was the path that brought you there?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Good boy.

utterances.speaker: MEHR
utterances.sentences: My wife and I, together, were able to participate in an Ayahuasca ceremony. My wife was going through postpartum depression. It was a really difficult time for our family. The experience was life-changing.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Dr. Mehr left the ER to open Cascade Psychedelic Medicine in 2021. He started with ketamine, a legal anesthetic that's been used since the '70s. It was approved by the FDA in 2019 to help people with treatment resistant depression.Dr. Mehr gave me a tour of where he plans to conduct psilocybin treatments. It feels a little different from what I imagined your ER environment would be.

utterances.speaker: MEHR
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh, yes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And notice the instruments.

utterances.speaker: MEHR
utterances.sentences: I use the gong, the singing bowls. This is called a tongue drum. It's like a hand pan.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: You use all these?

utterances.speaker: NEHR
utterances.sentences: All of them.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: He showed me his vision for a mushroom therapy session.

utterances.speaker: MEHR
utterances.sentences: Let's go ahead and lay this back. Get comfortable with the blanket.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: This is a doctor's office and experience unlike any I've seen before.

utterances.speaker: MEHR
utterances.sentences: I'll just start to kind of slow down your body, start to slow down your mind.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Calming and cozy. I was asleep within minutes. No meds needed.Like Dr. Mehr, Mike Arnold, who founded Silo Wellness and launched its Jamaica Retreat, plans to open a service center in Oregon, much bigger than the one-on-one model. What is this place?

utterances.speaker: MIKE ARNOLD, FOUNDER, SILO WELLNESS
utterances.sentences: So Laurelwood Center is over 150,000 square feet. For our purposes, we'll build to house lecturers from all over the world to come and talk about right living, talk about consciousness, talk about the history of the medicine.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Division, bring Jamaica to Oregon, hosting simpler, more affordable psilocybin retreats on the grounds of this former Christian boarding school.Psilocybin makes us, as you see, a better version of what we are.

utterances.speaker: ARNOLD
utterances.sentences: It is a tool to allow us to look at ourselves like as a disinterested third-party observer and have the opportunity to reframe our stories, to tell our stories differently.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: A tool Dr. Mehr is planning to use as soon as he can.What if I told you I was going to take psilocybin on camera and go through this experience?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Well, you had pause there, as you know, I'm like, shoot. Should I be worried?(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: MEHR
utterances.sentences: So you're doing this with -- you bring the crew down?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: We're all going, yes.

utterances.speaker: MEHR
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh. You guys all gone to Jamaica? OK. That's amazing. I'm so excited for you.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And on camera?

utterances.speaker: ARNOLD
utterances.sentences: What are your biggest fears?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: I think the breaking of my brain is a concern.

utterances.speaker: ARNOLD
utterances.sentences: You make a living on that brain.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Some days.

utterances.speaker: ARNOLD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Since it's operating, yes.

utterances.speaker: BARRETT
utterances.sentences: We think that one of the ways that psilocybin is working in the brain is by allowing for a period of plasticity, like, imagine heating up some clay so that it can be molded into a different form.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: You describe a psilocybin experience as shaking the snow globe. What do you mean by that? CARHART-HARRIS

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Dr. Robin Carhart-Harris is going to see if psilocybin physically changes anything in my brain.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: How's it going in there?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: All good.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We're going to do some structural scans now.CARHART-HARRIS: With the cabling scan, we can look at the health of the fibers. We'll see their health before and after your trip to Jamaica.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And the trip while in Jamaica. Trip, I guess they'll be doing.I'm somebody who's kind of always played by the rules on things. Didn't drink before it was legal. And it was an opportunity to try to go back and relive a bit with a bit more hopefully clarity what the past few years were like. Mic check 1, 2, 3. I think about the past few years in China and reporting at the start of what was then a mystery illness. Over here, I've had this backpack for now several weeks. To have lived in China for the duration of pretty extreme lockdowns. Morning of leaving Shanghai in the midst of what's been now 50 days in lockdown. Being away from family, the guilt of missing out on loved one's funerals. So I'm hoping maybe psilocybin will just be a journey in of itself that allows me to process some of that. I hope by taking mushrooms, I might also better understand Jason and Johanna's mind altering trips. They're allowing us in on something so personal, so private, beginning with the preparation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How are we all doing today?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: In the weeks leading up to our retreat, we all get to know each other over Zoom calls.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And it's important to talk about synesthesia.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: We're also tasked with journaling.Across town in LA, Johanna journaling the questions she wants answered. Can you read a little bit of this?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Yes. So this is my first question. Am I grounded? I don't feel grounded. I think I tend to look at the negative side of life. I want to let go of what is not serving me.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Back in South Carolina, Jason's confident that Magic Mushrooms will help him stop drinking.J.MOSS: Can you get all this stuff printed out? P. MOSS: It could be nothing if you want it to be or it can be everything, you know, you're really just unlocking doors. I feel like they haven't been unlocked. J. MOSS: Yes. P.MOSS: My only fear is that you'll go without doing any soul searching. J. MOSS: I'm going to. I'm completely open. I'm an open book for this. P. MOSS: I don't want you to look at it as like, I'm doing this because it's going to make me stop drinking. J. MOSS: That's the ultimate goal.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Nice, huh?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I like it.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: We arrived in Jamaica feeling the warm island welcome.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How was the ride? Solomon [ph].

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It was good.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: James.And you stranger?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How are you?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nice to see you again.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Sure. I'm here as a journalist, but I'm also a fellow retreat participant taking psilocybin for the first time. With my doctor's sign off, I feel ready. Or so I told myself.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We're going to do a little something now.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: We start with group meetings to open up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What is the medicine need to teach me? What is the plant medicine, the mushrooms have that I need to know to be happy, to not be depressed? CULVER

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Relaxing your chest.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Palms of our hands together.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And scenic yoga. Complete with a musical encore.(MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: You slowly realize mushrooms play a pretty small role in this larger therapeutic journey. Most of it is focused on connecting with nature and each other.As it hits you, do you feel like you can relax yet? Or are you --

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Do you feel excited?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do.

utterances.speaker: JOHANNA BUITRON, RETREAT PARTICIPANT
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I have that nervousness of just the unknown.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: I think about what could happen afterwards, and I know they could have a creative surge, and that sounds amazing. By, like, part of me thinks can it break what I --

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: What you have?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Like, can it mess it up? Do either of you worry about that?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I never worry about that because I've seen my friends do it recreationally, and they are perfectly fine.CULVER (voiceover):  We start our second day meeting with Ben Mannix.

utterances.speaker: BEN MANNIX, VETERAN PSILOCYBIN HOLISTIC THERAPIST
utterances.sentences: Listen to yourself. What do you feel? What do you feel is right?CULVER (voiceover):  She's the lead facilitators for our retreat, working to assess how much psilocybin we should take. MANNIX:  This is part of your journey. CULVER (voiceover):  We also share our intentions going into the journey.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: Johanna?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Showing me parts of myself that I don't value right now. Maybe looking for self-worth, but mainly clarity. That would be like my main intention. So, I'm very open to what it brings.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Being open to what I encounter in this space. Meeting myself in a childlike state, kind of, seeing what I find there.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I know that when I'm going through it, I know what I'm going to be focusing on is trying to find out. So, it's going to be discovery.CULVER (voiceover):  We're given a few hours before the dosing ceremony to catch our breath, soak in the sea, and ready our minds and bodies. When we're ready, we begin with a meditation.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: Choose a place, a place that you already know, and this place is going to be your safe place. And just start moving your hands, rubbing your hands, slowly moving your arms, moving your legs, your feet. And when you're ready, slowly you can open your eyes. Ready?CULVER (voiceover):  Ben hands us our doses. No actual mushrooms. The psilocybin already extracted and put in the form of chocolates and capsules.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: This is for you.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: This is for you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: Enjoy your journey.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.CULVER (voiceover):  It's a slow start and not all that exciting. 15 minutes in --

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Do you feel anything, Jason?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: How about you?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Nothing. Just relaxed. But that might have been the meditation before.CULVER (voiceover):  A few minutes later --

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Are you feeling it?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Heart beating.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: I feel my face and, like, my jaw.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: A little numb?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I feel pretty much the same.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: Do you think that you're trying to resist?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm looking forward. I can't believe I'm the only person out here now.CULVER (voiceover):  Frustrated yet determined, Jason decides to lie down. The eye masks and earplugs supposed to help us delve deeper inside ourselves. Hours passed, and as you can see, I'm restless.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: How are you?CULVER (voiceover):  Johanna still feeling the psilocybin but already processing some of her experience.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: There is like one side that is like, oh, you need to be perfect. You need to do this. And then the other side that is like, I don't care.CULVER (voiceover):  Jason hardly moving. As it begins to wear off, I feel groggy and tired. I find it difficult to talk. [20:40:00] CULVER:  How are you feeling?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I'm feeling good. I'm still, like, landing.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: It's funny you said that because I felt like I was in a flight through some of it.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: My mind is, like -- going like a thousand miles per hour. I have a lot of ideas. I grab my journal, and I'm like, OK, I need to write. And then when I open my eyes, I'm like, OK. I don't know where to start.CULVER (voiceover):  Hearing about Johanna's journey makes me think mine was not nearly as profound. No visual distortions and certainly no rush of ideas.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh, Johanna, I think I need to go much deeper now. I felt restless and bored.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Bored?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I felt bored.CULVER (voiceover):  Jason is the last one out, not up for talking.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I got to get this mic off me.CULVER (voiceover):  The next day we meet with Daphne White, the retreat's integration specialist. She focuses on helping us apply our psilocybin experiences to our daily lives. DAPHNE WHITE, RETREAT'S INTEGRATION SPECIALIST:  Now, that you've had like a day to reflect, how would you summarize your experience?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I will say it was -- more like a roller coaster.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: A roller coaster?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Yes. It, kind of, started, like, very soft. Then when you cover your eyes, you kind of go deep.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: And it just -- it feels like you're, like, in a movie. Then you just, like, you start running super-fast. And then for sure you feel like your inner voice talking to you.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Do you notice that you're seeing things differently or showing up differently just as yourself in the world?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I think it gave me more a peace of mind.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Maybe a trusting in the universe. Something like you got this. You know what you're doing. Answers will come. CULVER

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: What would I say is coming up for you most when you wake up this morning?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: The word "more."

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Just more.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: I mean, there's just more --

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: -- more to do.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I was expecting it to kind of kick in quickly. I didn't have any psychoactive experience.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: It's OK.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: It was -- I guess the only word I can think of is, like, I was a little underwhelmed. I was expecting something pretty profound, and that, of course, didn't happen.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: We got everybody?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All right. Let's get this show on the road.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Yes, let's go.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: All right. Let's do it.CULVER (voiceover):  Needing to decompress a bit, we go on a little hike.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Where are we going, to the spring?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We are going to the bat cave and the Bob Marley mineral spring.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Maybe I'm just frustrated based on what yesterday was. But I'm not --

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: The buildup of the --

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think there was a lot of buildup. Maybe that's on me, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I certainly have that. I felt not remarkably disappointed, but I didn't feel that, like --

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: I think I'm just hopeful for the next one.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So, let's venture in the cave, should we?

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: The bat cave, yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The holes are -- those are where the bats go inside on the top there.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: You can see them flying.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You've got to be careful. The spring is under the cave. All right. Push off. Let go. Let go. Let go off the rope. Yes, man.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's just nice.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Why did you get into this line of work?

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: I think because I want to help people.CULVER (voiceover):  On our walk back, Ben reassures me ahead of tomorrow's final dose.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: I'd be intrigued to see what the second ceremony will do.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm. I'd like to just, like, trust the process.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: I say, very -- always, trust the process.CULVER (voiceover):  Going into our fourth day of the retreat.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: My intentions are, perhaps, just a self-awakening or self- awareness.CULVER (voiceover):  Jason and I prepare to take double our first dose.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And I want to see where it takes me.CULVER (voiceover):  I know it seems like a big jump, but I'm good with it, especially with folks like M.J. around. She's a psychiatric nurse who spent years treating patients experiencing negative reactions to psychedelics.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And I think we come with the expectation that maybe it's going to break your brain, you know, or do something that's going to make you regret ever having taken anything here.DR. MARION JOHNSON, REGISTERED NURSE, SILO WELLNESS:  So, that's why the screening process is so vigorous to come in because, you know, obviously there's some diagnoses that we're just not ready to have out here on an island.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: It's not for everybody.DR. JOHNSON:  It's not for everybody.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes.DR. JOHNSON:  There's a process to make sure it's -- that you're able to come here and safely dose.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes.DR. JOHNSON:  And I will be by your side, and so will Ben. CULVER (voiceover):  Ben grinds the mushrooms into a tea for our final ceremony.

utterances.speaker: MANNIX
utterances.sentences: So, you can please stir.CULVER (voiceover):  This time, Jason the first to lie down.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm not really feeling that much, but I figure, you know, just getting relaxed.CULVER (voiceover):  I'll see you, guys.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: One by one, we follow.CULVER (voiceover):  After an hour, still nothing. The facilitators watching on begin to wonder why we're not responding.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Are you going to updose him?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Huh?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Are you updosing him?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We stick to the process. I let go -- the universe.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Oddly, I get transported to Cuba a lot. And I feel my grandmother's energy.CULVER (voiceover):  The visual distortions you hear about, yes, we're seeing those.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: It sounds -- check out those palm tree, and it's kind of funny.CULVER (voiceover):  Vivid and vibrant and a bit freaky at times.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I mean, I know it's a palm tree, but it's weird. It's kind of blue, it's purple.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I'm here. I'm, like, I have all these things in my head, right? So, it feels good to, like, put them on paper.CULVER (voiceover):  I, too, suddenly sense a creative drive. I need my journal from my room. But I realize I don't have my key.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes, key, throw it. Key.CULVER (voiceover):  Producer Natalie to the rescue. Back in my bed, I write and write and write, or so it seemed. The effects come in waves. And things get more physical for me. Jason keeps smiling throughout. Maybe that means it's working this time. Tough to tell. The effects start to lessen, and I'm hungry, exhausted, but at ease.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.DR. JOHNSON:  All right. You did a great job. CULVER (voiceover):  The next day, before we all head out, Daphne helps us process our experiences.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: That was a trip. It's definitely a trip. I did have a moment of thinking, oh, my gosh, I have a profound urge to write. And I remember being so intent on what I was writing. And then reading it now, I mean, it's one line that is, this is a place you return to. You know, it's one thing to have these visions of distortions, but then when I would close my eyes and I would feel touched, I would then feel, like, a shock of energy. It was mostly my grandmother's that came through.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: And my grandmother died while I was in China, and so I couldn't get back for that.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: It's OK.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think this setting helped a lot because my grandmother's Cuban. And like --

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes. And so, I felt like I was on -- in Havana and like -- all I can say was, it was what I needed.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Last day before we head home.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I know, yes.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: How are you feeling about that part?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I'm feeling pretty confident, like, peaceful, refreshed. And I got the answers that I was looking for. I think this will be, like, a good guide for me to start reshaping my life.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: How are you today?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Feeling fantastic.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely fantastic. It was quite the reboot.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Is there anything you want to share, anything you're curious about that came up for you?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: So, the first thing we're going to do is the sound calibration.DR. ROBIN CARHART-HARRIS, DIRECTOR OF PSYCHEDELICS DIVISION, NEUROSCAPE AT UCSF:  So, this is looking at the cabling of the brain.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Dr. Carhart-Harris compared my brain to a study he conducted with people who were also taking psilocybin for the first time.DR. CARHART-HARRIS:  So, we have looked at this cabling in another study when you age into your older years, then those cables start to fray. And we found that went down one month after psilocybin. And it's the opposite of what happens with older aging and pathologies of brain aging.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Antiaging?DR. CARHART-HARRIS:  So, it's like an antiaging effect. And we saw that in a group of about 30 people. CULVER (voiceover):  Dr. Carhart-Harris is submitting his study to a leading scientific journal for review. DR. CARHART-HARRIS:  Because of all that, we were excited and motivated to do the same analysis on your brain. Are you ready for this? And what we found was in entirely consistent.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness. Wow.DR. CARHART-HARRIS:  So, the brain is certainly intact.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Not broken, perhaps even better.DR. CARHART-HARRIS:  Yes. CULVER (voiceover):  We showed my results to an independent researcher who saw the same changes Dr. Carhart-Harris detected. While this research is in its early stages, more studies need to be done. There are a wide range of medical indications that are now being studied with psilocybin. But psilocybin has not led to a therapeutic outcome in everybody who's enrolled in the clinical trial. It's not going to work for everything, and we shouldn't expect it to work for everything. CULVER (voiceover):  While one of the retreat participants said it didn't work for her. Weeks later, in L.A., Johanna, still grateful for her journey.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Here we are, now more than a month out.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: I'm feeling, like, continued at peace. I mean, certain days, it can change.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: But, like, overall, at peace. What about you?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I'm doing things in my life that bring me more joy, like dancing, like traveling, like being with friends. And those decisions are changing my life.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I'm doing my work a lot better. And when I'm giving everything to my clients, all my clients starts referring, I'm booked for, like, two months.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: It's like a reciprocity in a different way.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Do you feel like this changed your life?

utterances.speaker: BUITRON
utterances.sentences: I think it gave me the push to change my life, for sure.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Come on, baby. Do something good. She's strong.CULVER (voiceover):  But perhaps the biggest change we've seen is Jason.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: That was a big one there. That's really --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So, how's it feel being home?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: It's been good so far. Everything's -- it feels more positive. And --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It seems like you're happier to do --

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it was just a complete change. It was just immediate. It's the first time in my life I felt like everything really connected. And it's very difficult to describe, but it worked. It worked.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: How is it coming back there?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: First of all, I felt better. I felt different.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Your intention going there was for something that you've been dealing with for a long time and struggling with --

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: -- with alcohol.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: There's no temptation. There's no thought. There's no thought of using it in a wave that relieve stress or for sexual lubricant. It's just gone.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: What do you need to do to sustain it?

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: I've thought about that. I'm making these long-term goals. And do I need to get counseling for this? And thus far, no, because it was that quick.

utterances.speaker: CULVER
utterances.sentences: When I checked in with you probably a week after, right, you say, as an update, not only has the experience completely diminished and erased any thought of alcohol, but I am experiencing a profound increased cognitive ability. I don't think I've ever felt this industrious and clear minded in my lifetime.

utterances.speaker: MOSS
utterances.sentences: That's correct. Absolutely correct. And it's almost, like, every part of your brain, all of a sudden, just started working together in a different way, in a different fashion. That's the mindset. It's as if I've never ever drank before. And I thought of, it's not even there. That is remarkable to me. An absolute gift. And a life-changer. Absolute life-changer.(END VIDEO CLIP)
